instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
Hi there!

Have a 2015 12 incher here without any liquid damage and no sign of life.

Customer had told me that battery life was all over the place the last time it worked and since then nothing!

It can't be the battery because when i disconnect the battery it still doesn't do anything!
I have an amp meter hooked up. Says it's 20V with or without battery connected. and pulls around 0.15A without battery and 0.4A with battery

So it seems to be charging the battery somewhat

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message: Check for a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>. If so, <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> is very likely shorted to ground. It is a very very common issue on this model.

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message: Thank you! unfortunately, it's not shorted. could it be the charging port? I have one on order and it's coming soon to test or am I wasting my time with that?

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP> is not always really short.
It can cause a low value on <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> and nothing work then.
I suppose the board in question is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, confirm that.

You need to measure some voltages on the board.
Start posting resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> line; in diode mode, with red probe on ground.
Any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>, F7140?

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
Changed the charging port just in case, same issue.,

yes <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> isd the board 


<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> in diode mode is 0.307 at <RESISTOR>R6952</RESISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> is 20V
F7140 8.6 V on both ends

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message: im getting 20v at <CAPACITOR>C7002</CAPACITOR> even through according to my board view it's supposed to be <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H</SIGNAL> which is 8.6... am i onto something here?

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message: could there be voltage leaking into <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is closer to 3.3v than to 3v which is what it's supposed to be

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> is 20V"
Means the USB-C port is OK, SMC already "talked" with charger.

<CAPACITOR>C7000</CAPACITOR>-2 are not connected on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> rail...
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> is the input rail for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power supply.
It comes out from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> only to connect 3 filter caps (<CAPACITOR>C7000</CAPACITOR>-2).
The control block, drivers and output MOSFETs of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power supply are integrated in <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

"F7140 8.6 V on both ends"
As you already got correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, follow the Power On Sequence now.
Check signals and powers at <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and PCH System Power Management block.

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
Sorry to be a pain, i'm really confused by your last post. I'm stuck :(

Could you rephrase? thank you!

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
"F7140 8.6 V on both ends"
If you also get 3.3V at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, forget about <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; it does what supposed to do.

Now check the 4 PCH's RTC signals, 32KHz from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> react when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal?

threads.title: 2015 12 inch macbook - no liquid damage. No sign of life
threads.message:
I got same Mac with exactly same issue and behaviour.
It was fixed by replacing SN650801 - <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
